column1: 2015M&PS...50.1449S|2015|Exploring the Moon's surface for remnants of the lunar mantle 1. Dunite xenoliths in mare basalts. A crustal or mantle origin?|Shearer
column10: Clive R.|Meteoritics and Planetary Science|50|8|1449|Remotely sensed observations from recent missions (e.g.
column13: Chandrayaan-1) have been interpreted as indicating that the deep crust and upper mantle are close to or at the lunar surface in many large impact basins (e.g.
column17: the capability of either impact or volcanic processes to transport mantle lithologies to the lunar surface should be enhanced in these regions. Somewhat problematic to these observations and interpretations is that examples of mantle lithologies in the lunar sample collection (Apollo Program
column19: lunar meteorites) are at best ambiguous. Dunite xenoliths in high-Ti mare basalt 74275 are one of these ambiguous examples. In this high-Ti mare basalt
column20: olivine occurs in three generations: olivine associated with dunite xenoliths
column22: and olivine microphenocrysts. The dunite xenoliths are anhedral in shape and are generally greater than 800 μm in diameter. The interior of the xenoliths are fairly homogeneous with regard to many divalent cations. For example
column23: the Mg# (Mg/Mg + Fe × 100) ranges from 82 to 83 in their interiors and decreases from 82 to 68 over the 10-30 μm wide outer rim. Titanium and phosphorus X-ray maps of the xenolith illustrate that these slow diffusing elements preserve primary cumulate zoning textures. These textures indicate that the xenoliths consist of many individual olivine grains approximately 150-200 μm in diameter with low Ti
column25: and P cores. These highly incompatible elements are enriched in the outer Fe-rich rims of the xenoliths and slightly enriched in the rims of the individual olivine grains. Highly compatible elements in olivine such as Ni exhibit a decrease in the rim surrounding the xenolith
column26: an increase in the incompatible element depleted cores of the individual olivine grains
column27: and a slight decrease in the "interior rims" of the individual olivine grains. Inferred melt composition
column29: and zoning profiles enable the reconstruction of the petrogenesis of the dunite xenoliths. Preservation of primary magmatic zoning (Ti
column31: Al) and lack of textures similar to high-pressure mineral assemblages exhibited by the Mg-suite (Shearer et al. 2015) indicate that these xenoliths do not represent deep crustal or shallow mantle lithologies. Further
column32: they are chemically and mineralogically distinct from Mg-suite dunites identified from the Apollo 17 site. More likely
column33: they represent olivine cumulates that crystallized from a low-Ti mare basalt at intermediate to shallow crustal levels. The parent basalt to the dunite xenolith lithology was more primitive than low-Ti basalts thus far returned from the Moon. Furthermore
column34: this parental magma and its more evolved daughter magmas are not represented in the basalt sample suite returned from the Taurus-Littrow Valley by the Apollo 17 mission. The dunite xenolith records several episodes of crystallization and re-equilibration. During the last episode of re-equilibration
column35: the dunite cumulate was sampled by the 74275 high-Ti basalt and transported over a period of 30-70 days to the lunar surface.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/maps.12480

column1: 1996LPI....27.1249S|1996|Pyroxenes from Lunar High-Ti Mare Basalts: Oxygen Analysis by Electron Microprobe and Estimates of Ti^3+/Ti^4+|Spilde
column4: J. J.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference|27||1249|Analysis of oxygen on the electron microprobe has been seldom done in the past. The measurement of oxygen (and other light elements) has its share of unique problems
column5: such as weak signal due to the low fluorescence yield of low atomic numbers and the high absorption of their X-rays
column6: along with other problems that have lead to the usual condition in mineral analysis of calculating oxygen from the stoichiometry of the mineral analyzed. However
column7: with the advent of synthetic multi-layer analyzing crystals with large d-spacing and improved matrix correction methods
column8: the direct measurement of oxygen can yield additional information. For example
column9: by measuring O on hydrous minerals and glasses
column10: close estimates of H2O can reached. In anhydrous minerals
column11: in which one or more constituents have variable oxidation states
column12: the valance states may be determined by calculation from the oxygen analysis. Here we attempt to measure oxygen in pyroxene from Apollo 17 high-Ti mare basalt 74275. This a quickly-cooled basalt with TiO2 ~ 13 wt% and TiO2 in pyroxene >6.0 wt%. Our goal in this study is to estimate Ti3+/Ti4+.|

column1: 1980LPSC...11..251D|1980|Chemistry and liquidus phase relations of Apollo 15 red glass: implications for the deep lunar interior.|Delano
column2: J. W.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||251|Electron microprobe analyses indicate that the Apollo 15 red glasses with 13.8 wt.% TiO2 were produced in a volcanic fire-fountain. They are composed of three chemical groups connected by a pronounced trend. The liquidus phase relations are compatible with the view that the most Mg-rich group (A) was produced by partial melting of Ti-rich cumulates at a depth of about 480 km. The other red glasses (B and C) may have been derived from the group A magma by fractional crystallization at pressures less than 5 kbar. The fact that high-Ti mare liquids were produced at depths greatly in excess of 100 km requires an important revision of cumulate-remelting models. It is suggested that 4.4-AE cumulate rockbergs sank into the deep lunar interior soon after the global differentiation event. These blocks have a wide range of compositions and underwent partial melting at depths of 400 to 500 km to produce low- and high-Ti magmas.|

column9: which indicates that 74275 was 50% undersaturated at the time of eruption.|

column6: L. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||383|In order to understand the origin of differing ilmenite/armalcolite textural relationships
column8: oxygen fugacity and cooling rate have been experimentally investigated. Results show that armalcolite and ilmenite compositions are dependent upon the liquid composition and temperature at the time of crystallization. Furthermore
column9: the different armalcolite/ilmenite textures rely to a greater extent on f<SUB>O2</SUB> than on cooling rate or bulk rock composition

column2: G.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2001|Nuclear particle track measurements in the 68 cm double drive tube 74002-74001 indicate that the whole core was deposited in one event some 10 m.y. ago. Significant reworking of the soil only occurred down to a few cm from the lunar surface since this event. Complementary investigations in this core by other groups are discussed. Most of the evidence available leads to a two stage model in which the orange and black soils collected at Shorty Crater were first irradiated for approximately 25 m.y. at some depth and then were deposited only a few m.y. ago as an overturned ejecta blanket.|

column1: 1978LPSC....9.1981B|1978|Depositional and irradiational history and noble gas contents of orange-black droplets in the 74002/1 core from Shorty Crater.|Bogard
column4: W. C.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1981|Isotopic concentrations of noble gases were assessed in grain size separates of 14 soils from a 67-cm section of lunar regolith taken on the rim of Shorty Crater. The orange-black droplets in this section were probably formed from pyroclastic eruptions about 3.6 billion years ago; they give little indication of surface exposure. The isotopic concentrations suggest that cosmic ray irradiation of the core occurred in two stages and that the core stratigraphy was inverted between stages. The first irradiation stage may have taken place immediately after pyroclastic deposition of the droplets and could have lasted about 20 million years.|

column1: 1978LPSC....9...59J|1978|Trace element evidence for a laterally inhomogeneous moon.|Jovanovic
column5: Jr.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||59|A number of trace element interrelationships support the concept of a laterally inhomogeneous moon based originally on Clr/P2O5 ratios. The correspondence between Clr/P2O3 and Rb/Sr ratios in basalts are of special interest since the isotropic evolution of the latter pair of elements relates to the earliest history of the moon. This implies the times when the Clr/P2O5 relationships were established. The early magma ocean is conjectured to have been made up of non-intermixing seas resulting either from large convection cells or large body accretion. These mutually exclusive regions could be lunar geological provinces. It is proposed that the diversity of basalts from the Apollo 17 site is related to the lateral inhomogeneity of the moon. Ca/Na ratios in basalts show a trend which parallels that of Ru/Os and in a corresponding fashion may serve as a depth indicator.|
